verbatim_example: What I'm wondering is how long after my last dose of bupe will it be before it is again effective for a rapid opiates detox?
I've done it once before. I went from daily half teenth IV dope to nothing after a week of using gradually reduced doses of bupe.

I always imagined a year to be this huge milestone where I'd have done loads of work on myself and be almost as normal as any other person in the streets. But it's passed so quickly and, if anything, I'm only discovering more ways in which I'm hurt and broken and want to recover from.
I will say that I avoided many common opiate withdrawal symptoms this time around, no unbearable RLS, no violent sneezing or yawning

But I'm 4 months sober and know my life is going in the positive direction. But it's so fucking hard to stay sober when I still feel so empty and just bored everyday. I know that drugs are temporary and make you worse off in the long run. But I just don't use today and do the same thing tomorrow.
I've been 4 months sober. I'm doing better now with my cravings.

We have the strength to do it. I know you all do. If I can you can. ... Sobriety comes with real emotion, drive, initiative, charisma, some pain from the wreckage of our past, true insight, real friends who care about you and who you actually care about. So many many many great things! ... Just know the life after addiction waiting for you is far far far beyond greater than any drug high.
haven't had any opis in months
What can I do to make it thru detox without killing myself (or really wanting to).
Hopefully this gives someone hope. I couldn't have done it without this community. Thank u for saving my life
Now that I am clean, I can barely get out of bed bc back and knees are so bad. How the fuck do I live like this.
I am scared bc I know I will want to use. I am scared bc i am new in my recovery.
So, ya obvs 26 days clean. Still having restless legs, but my regular Dr says they're not related, which means that the only withdrawal symptom I had was insomnia
I am happy to be here, sober . I am starting to really mourn for ten years I lost to oxycontin and Xanax.
I was very upfront about​ my recovery
I celebrated by not using. It was hard, so hard to actually deal with all that pain, and all of those emotions, but I made it. By the grace of God, I didn't use.
Six months ago I couldn't even go 60 minutes without having to use something
If I can do it, any of you guys can
used to run one in r/opiates but figured I could get some people who actually could participate in the entire season
If I can do it any of you can.  Do what works for you.  My recovery won’t work for you, like your’s won’t work for me.
What a difference a year can make
Find what works for you and stick to it.

It's day 3 off of a 8 day relapse... Only 3-4 hours of sleep last night. Forced down a small meal and vitamins this morning. About to head to work smack at the start of day 3. It's gonna be tough but it won't kill me.
whatever time you have cleared, you never have to do that part again
Dropping the Lope to 4mg and possibly the same GABA/Kpin dosage
I have accomplished quite a bit over days 1-5, I can't forget about that. Those are days I don't have to relive, today has been the hardest thus far.
One week down, working on day 8. So far I haven't been a huge crybaby like yesterday. Instead it's just a emotional void, no good or bad. I'll take that over just bad.
Eight days down, moving into day 9

I still cry like a baby sometimes but less frequently. I still blow up the bathroom in the morning but it doesn't persist all day. I still can't sleep well but I'm grabbing more random spurts of it. I'm noticing glimmers. Sometimes they come and go in an instant, sometimes they stick around a few minutes, sometimes I can stretch them for 1-2 hours. Piece by piece, glimmer by glimmer, I'm working to rebuild.

but that shouldn't be the reason you don't stop using. It's not supposed to be easy, you're trying to rescue your hijacked brain and body from something that's held it hostage for however long. The effort you put in is just that... EFFORT. The more effort you put in, the more manageable you're gonna make the symptoms and obstacles.
Getting a lot of exercise. Haven't missed a day of work. Sleep is trying to return slowly. Not as many emotional spells. Appetite is coming back (especially after exercise).
Not sure if I've ever experienced the 'pink cloud' before... Just sticking to my daily regiment/diet etc and waiting for a wave of reprieve from this next phase

I immediately got up with one of my biggest supporters, played the tape of days 1-7, took some deep breaths (maybe smoked a bit of weed) and went on a jog with my dog. I can't fuckin do it. Eventually I replied to him with the supportive route and asked him what his plan was to get a handle on himself again

Feeling better every day, looking forward to maybe sleeping in this weekend?, Energy/happiness comes in more spurts with less feelings of gloom and doom. I feel like I'm trying to slowly step back into the shell of my old self that I've been hovering outside of for the last year.

Other than that it's a mental game at this point. I'm starting an adaptogen blend on top my other shit I take today. Anyone have experience with adaptogens? After a lot of research I've found that people use them for clean energy and lowering inflammation in the brain/body, therefore lowering anxiety and depression spells.

Symptoms at 3 weeks out... broken sleep of 4-6 hours, morning shits (a very zen one this morning at least), anhedonia waves, come and go restless limbs. Hoping some of the above starts to clear out over the next week.
Only things lingering around at 25 days are morning GI, restless sleep, anxiety/anhedonia waves. I think it's gradually getting better but it feels sort of consistent over the last few days.
I've gone this long. I feel so much better than I thought I would. I have an appetite. being off dope feels so good
I have been off heroin for six days now
Hang in there. It gets better. I'm already doing much better.
Each one is one closer to being better
I think I can do this. I haven't thought that in so long time even when I made it to three days before
Im still only a few days clean, but im not turning back
You can do it. I know it.
Stick with it. I was hopeless. If I can do it, you can.
Just because we're addicts doesn't mean we need to go through withdrawals. I hope all of you have a happy, healthy, and safe day. Be careful out there.
Do NOT put any piss back into your bladder! This is how you get a serious infection, fuck up your bladder, and become incontinent, and have to wear diapers the rest of your life.
My WD kit is an old Jurassic Park lunch box. Contained within are some thing to either get rid of, or help ease WD symptoms.

I'm going to take my 60 day chip today. I'm actually looking forward to it, rather than mocking the whole process. The days where I feel out of control and anxious are farther and farther apart. I'm sleeping now, my work has improved, my family is happier and my hope has increased exponentially.
I've got 4 months clean and sober - the idea of being in pain just riles me up. I know that there is no chance in hell that I can have any opiates without coming unhinged.
We can do it, and it's not shameful to be afraid and work through that fear with others
I'm writing this and calling my sponsor today so that I'm honest, and keeping myself accountable.

My only intention here is to be helpful to others, as well as to my self! Writing and sharing really helps me with my own recovery. ... Some advice that has helped me tremendously along my journey through recovery.
I encourage anyone who wants to make that change to realize that you already do know, in your heart, that you are fully capable of changing.

Myself as well as the large majority of opiate users I have met along my journey through recovery all have almost the same story... And those drugs are made by... the same companies that make the Percocet and the Oxy, etc. Seems to me they have figured out how to keep the money flowing, even when their previous ‘customers’ decide it’s time to stop.

if someone who is on subs, methadone, or using, and has been wanting to jump off/get clean... Since you are already experiencing all of the terrible physical symptoms whether you like it or not, I wonder if this situation would make it “easier” both physically and mentally, since you know you are going to feel that way regardless of using or not.

I just want to write this so that those who are in the state and/or timeframe that I was in at this point two years ago to know that it gets so, so much better. ... Don’t let this shit define you. Instead, let it be something that maybe did define you for a little bit, or however long, but now YOU define IT as a bad time in your life- but a time in which you realized what was happening- and during which you took back control. ... Take that one baby step- that could lead toward a path that you will one day look back on and be so unbelievably grateful for and proud of.
Clean for over two years... Why am I still searching this shit.
I haven't touched an opiate in over two years, haven't shot up in almost three

For all the people in early recovery, don’t complain about rehab, sober living, or meetings. Enjoy it, have fun, cherish the people you are meeting and create lifelong connections.  Be grateful we got to experience some real ass shit in our life. Most people don’t.

Please everyone, get clean and stay clean. Life is so much more than an early death to an OD and being an addict with nothing to live for. It’s not worth it, not even once.  Get out of the mindset that you’re smarter than this, you’re absolutely not and understand the consequences addiction can bring.
Recovery is hard. I just have to remember I’m on the right path right now.

Please. If you're thinking of trying heroin please please please do not do it. It's not fun anymore. Please don't do it. Please listen to the good people here who tell you not to fuck with it. Please don't make the same mistake I made.
I'm done with this bullshit lifestyle. ... Good bye heroin, I might miss you but I ain't taking you back.
So if you’re getting sober, don’t give up. Just wanted to put it out there!
I no i need to pick myself up as soon as i can
I will be starting on day 1 tomorrow
Im 1 week heroin free. Not feel well today
Today i am 15 days off heroin. Feeling depressed still but im waiting to here back from doctor about antideoressants
Today i am at day 20 heroin and alcohol free
Today is 34 days without heroin and alcohol
Im day 39 heroin and alcohol free
Today i am on day 50 heroin and alcohol free
I am 23 days off alcohol and 27 off Heroin. That is good as i plan to keep the days going up :)
I am still getting used to being clean
I've spent my first 6 days reading about how to not feel terrible
Getting sober REALLY is awesome. Here is my thought process on this from day 1 until now, just so you can get an idea of what it might look like for you.
To anyone that is hesitant to go, or thinks their recovery program doesn't need NA, I urge you to give it a shot. And don't just go one day, give it an honest chance.
when people ramble about shit that has absolutely no relevance to recovery

I've accepted that I'm not only an opiate addict, but I'm an ADDICT ADDICT. No mind altering chemicals for me. And I truly do hope that if you're an addict, that you find peace in your recovery, however you do it.
I go to 8 meetings a week, and have 62 days
I think I would wish for my own place. Living with my parents is alright, but I feel like it's holding me back from being independent (which I feel is an important part of recovery)
staying self aware and in the moment which is a huge part of recovery and growing as a person

I've never been with someone younger than me let alone 7 years; in fact I've pretty much only been with older girls. But her actual age doesn't really bother me. She's cool as fuck and has obviously been through a fair amount, already being in NA at that age. There's just something about it though... The whole one year rule is in the back of my mind. How can I expect someone to be where I need them to be, if I'm not where I need me to be? I cant just hit it and quit it either, cause that's just a shitty thing to do to someone, especially in early recovery.
Life keeps on getting better. My life is filled with so much love instead of the bullshit it was filled with for so long
I'm pretty confident I'd be using if it wasn't for NA
Recovery is possible. It's definitely not easy at all but I guarantee that the results are beautiful.
I've gained back most of my parents trust, I'm doing great in school, I'm chip chick at a meeting I regularly go to, and I have friends that actually care about me

To anyone who is in early recovery, I want to tell you that it is possible to enjoy life without drugs. I didn't believe it was possible a few months ago but as time went on and I began going to meetings and realizing what life was really about was when I became happier.
There’s government programs available as well as rehabs such as BFC who do financial assistance.

I'm sure lots of you could probably relate. I know what I'm doing is trying to replace one addiction with another, which isn't necessarily healthy. However this is where I'm at in my process so the best I can do is share about it, seek advice and take the right actions to move forward.

I support addicts getting help and going to treatment but you can't always force them to. Every addict has their own process and progression, they need to get to the point of desperation where they'll have a genuine desire for recovery.
if anyone has suggestions on how to keep busy and start enjoying everyday activities again I'd love to hear them
feel free to PM me if you need something or just want to talk to someone

I had no urge to buy today, but as soon as I had the pills in front of me I broke. Fuck I was doing so well, was already through the worst of the WDs. I have no willpower, I only hope that come tomorrow I'll be able to continue with my plan for sobriety in the new year.
I really want to STAY clean this time, and I'm hoping some of you guys will have advice on how to do so.
I quit dope about a month ago and have had really bad PAWS
45 days clean today and it’s been kinda rough lately
going through the withdrawals combined with not having any crutches will give me some enlightenment and allow me to completely focusing on recovery instead of worrying about my next nic fix
I just want to know how some of you get through that
reconnecting with some friends who I lost to my addiction

One thing that has helped greatly is the alternative addiction and support group I started running. Unlike other support groups around my area I utilize tools of the botanical variety. I give out for free Kratom, Kava Kava, CBD and other such things to help my members stay clean or get clean.

I use kratom to treat members of the group with better success than I've seen in most other programs. I'd like to spread the goodness with anyone who's trying to get clean or struggling to stay clean.

I know about the insomnia, and the RLS, and the aches, and the sweats, and the depression, and the anxiety, as this is not my first time being without the drug, but my first time I do not intend to use at my first opportunity in a while.
To all reading this looking for help or inspiration you CAN do it, trust me if I can, anyone can.
Does anyone have any advice on something that can help me sleep without aggravating the RLS?
Insomnia is starting to fade, restlessness no where near as bad, and the bit of mania I had last week seemed to have passed. Any ideas when I should return to normal?
All in all I'm counting myself thankful, cause the flu/cold is nothing compared to being strung out and having to use. No thank you.
Any advice or knowledge would be great

Main ways I've been able to **stay clean.** 1) **Support group.** 2) **Psychologist/Psychiatrist Meds.** 3) **Staying busy** 4) **Change your habits/lifestyle** 5) **Play the tape all the way through**

I've got about 6 months clean from an on/off whenever I could get it(percs>oxys>heroin>oxys>poppy seeds>heroin>oxy you get it) habit over last 12 years. Got serious over last 2 years moving to everyday.
To all you thinking of getting clean do it, you are loved, you are worth it.
Crying for almost no reason. I got dizzy and nauseous and angry
Hold on guys, we can kick this shit!
Not tempted, just tired and weak
after the hell of withdrawal I will never go down that road again
My sleep is wacky, I visit the bathroom an awful lot, but I'm HAPPY today
I have been clean for two weeks now. No opiates. No drinking. No caffeine. Easy does it, being as nice to brain & body as possible.
My body went through an absolute horror show of pain. Fever, shakes, nausea, muscle cramps... insomnia
I am clean, I am alive, I am beginning to feel comfortable in my skin
my colon has finally forgiven me
I went through hell getting clean. ... I am still clean. I am alive. And I am thankful.
I am five weeks sober. Grouchy, tired, but desperately glad to be alive
Hold on, guys, if you are just starting; it gets better and better.

I think about using sometimes, I do recognize that I am not immune to that pull. Life gets hard and I want to check out, but I don't. I remember how shit it was most of the time, how sick I got, how needy I became. I will not be a slave to a chemical.

Getting off the shit was hell. Now I do have to deal with everyday shit that I used to just block out, and I have some pain, but this is life. Beating the shit out of my mind and body is NOT worth it for a little perceived relief.

I'm fine. Every day is just a day now. I don't wake up in agony, thinking about a fix constantly. I just... live. Sometimes it's boring. I trudge through. I am alive, mostly happy and I know I am no longer slowly killing myself.

My first month or 2 out of rehab I opened up Google Calendar and I scheduled every single thing I was going to be doing for the week, and I stuck to it. If there was more than an hour of "watching tv/playing video games," I was finding something to do, even if it meant sitting with family. I did meetings a lot in the beginning, did a 90 in 90 and I slowly faded after that. I think the most important thing other than being honest is I structured my life again.

If you're just starting out I'll part with.. give yourself enough time for things to change. Give it your all everyday, prove anyone who thinks you'll never be shit... wrong. I'm nothing special, just someone who decided I was done fucking up. YOU CAN DO THIS.

I helped get him County funding to get into rehab. As soon as he got out he relapsed and went to jail. After jail he seemed to be doing great. He probably had close to 6 months. Working as a Barber and looking/sounding like his old self.

I think the most important thing is honesty but a close second for me was habit/process. I had a habit of getting high every day and it was my routine... it took a process to create a new one. I started scheduling my weeks in google calendar. From the moment I woke up til the time I laid down for bed, and I stuck to it. Eventually that came my habit and honestly what I do today isn’t very much different than that original calendar I made way back then, if anything a little more busy.

It started one day at a time and being honest and telling on myself. If Friday nights were hard for me and I would think about getting high I told people in my life I couldn't be alone on Friday nights.
I am 8 months sober from a heavy heroin habit
I'm kicking my first one month habit, between a half and full point a day. Wds have been easy but at this stage is it too late to get back to baseline?
How could I help her think more like me in terms of the importance (or lack thereof) of down and convince her to make time for some professional counselling?
kicked my h habit about 3 weeks ago and haven’t had the urge to use more than every now and then since
To my recovering bois, mad serious question
Day 5 and I feel so much better even though yesterday wasn't that bad. A little sleep deprived but overall feeling good
I'm over the worst why go right back. I'm just feeling trapped and depressed. But another day sober. Come on number 6.
Fought for sleep last night. No aches or anything like that just my brain could out run usain bolt

Now I have ran out of road and am now in the midst of finding a new path, one without all the obstacles. I feel like a have finally visualized a real life and what that is suppose to be composed of. I can now honestly say that I am ready to have a actual life and not this puppet show I have been putting on for everyone.
Stay clean everybody. The high isn't worth ruining your life.
Stay clean everybody and thank y'all for the support I have gotten here
Stay clean everybody and have a great weekend
Stay clean. Shit tends to work out in the end.
I PROMISE you, that not being chained to a pill or strip or powder is the way to go.
So my advice is do not use sub long term unless your ready and willing to taper very slowly and truly have the self control to do so. I highly highly advice this to anyone who's ready to quit.

To anyone out there who is on day 1 week 1 week 2 etc. I know how INSURMOUNTABLE it seems. But I PROMISE YOU if you just STAY THE FUCK AWAY FROM OPIATES, and have a vision of what you want your life to look like. It WILL fall into place.
it's been about 4 months off opiates and I have done it without any real support system besides my girlfriend and family
Still on the road to recovery but I am doing my best
Lope definitely helped my withdrawals the first three days and then when I woke up on the 4th day, I felt completely fine. ... You all can do this. Stay strong. It's worth it folks.
My withdrawals are never really that bad besides the sleep problem but I just take two extremely high doses of loperamide each 48 hours apart and before I know it i'm clear of the withdrawals
I am now 23 and feel like I need to get it right this time; I know I do not want to pick up. Will go to outpatient and meetings as much as I can.

I have meditated on and off, usually when I had a steady supply of heroin. Was doing a bundle a day but now im 24 days clean and focusing strictly on my psychical health (lifting/cardio) and mental health (meditation). Well just want to let you guys know it really does help.
Working out and meditating has saved me from wanting to ever use again

I am sober now and decided to take my dog to the lake... I would not have been outside and saw that duck if the cosmos did not align in such a way for me to stay sober now for 6 weeks and 3 days. Happy New Year friends. Stay sober and stay cool.
I could see how listening to this may help those earlier in recovery

If anybody needs any help at all or just wants to talk about their struggles, I am more than happy to give you some hope. Just remember, it's one step at a time. Getting off it is the hardest but the longer you go, the better your life will be.
How can I get out? I am working 6 days a week so there is never time to go through withdrawls. I can’t do this anymore
I survived day 1 (today) easy, I have no idea why I tried to do it myself 50 times when I should have come here right away. They make the W 80% better, I am at day 3 of W  but it feels like day 1.
I still have running lava from my ass and only sleep five hours a night... However I feel like my personality is back, I have dreams (goals), and feel pleasure from doing stuff again
how do you stay strong and did you exp some negative consequences?
I am giving my veins some time off
Being clean is hard but if I keep it up mabye some day I won’t have to keep fighting the urge to use or to kill myself
I made it about two and a half days, last dose was Wednesday afternoon...So I am basically going to go through it this time and need some support from you guys again to get through it.

I actually caved Friday morning and went to my guy and ended getting beat, the bags were 95% percent cut, I was just as sick after snorting it as I was before the fact. ... So I am basically going to go through it this time and need some support from you guys again to get through it.
I always end up relapsing around the 9 month mark, happened twice already. I know 9 months is a little ways away, but how do I stay true to myself this time around? Any suggestions?
hitting my first aa meeting this weekend since forever to which I’m looking forward to
I’m going to keep fighting just asking for some advice from the ones who are doing the damn thing. Anything helps. Thanks guys. I want 2018 to be a clean and happy year so bad
I’ve been waking up with a lot of anxiety which sucks but it does seem to fade once I start my day and get moving
What stuff did you do to help your brain recover faster?
I’m newly clean (got 10 days completely sober), and need help with my car (one of my main using spots)
What is the best medicine for withdrawaling to ease the symptoms?

If someone gives you a second chance please take it, while I'm still alive I have to bury myself out of this, I wish I had time to withdrawal when I had a job but no sick time no vacation hours and having a final warning for absences made it impossible,  lf I had a chance to clear my debt and start over I would not fuck it up, please weigh the pros and cons and learn from it
we don't have to worry about where money will come and trying to get through each day without having to WD
DONT COP AND DRIVE HIGH AF!

But by all means, use them and think that you are in the extreme minority of people that won't get hooked on the feeling because you've used pretty much all other classes of recreational drugs before (just like 95% of us on here). The best thing that can happen to you when you try it is that you wont really like the feeling of being on an opiate. Good luck, and please respect (and even fear) these drugs and where they can lead.
Started Suboxone today and doing IOP. Group therapy 5 times week, therapy and NA/SMART on top of it. Finally ready to make recovery my priority
I chose to go there instead of going out to the bar with friends to see a band. This is my first time taking the total abstinence path

It's day 5 for me, got to sleep in today which was nice, slept for about 9 hours. I'm really bored. Just counting down the hours till my 8 o clock meeting. Shared for the first time at NA last night. Got lots of hugs, phone numbers, and the white book. Can't believe I'm looking forward to tomorrow cause it means I get back to my 'normal' routine of therapy.
Today is day 13 for me! This is the longest I've been sober since summer 2011

It's day 20 for me. Tomorrow will be 3 weeks sober, which is incredible to me. This is already the most real clean time I've ever had without using illicit substances. Still fighting strep throat, which in early recovery really sucks. I'm staying strong though. I'm amazed how well managed my cravings are, and how normal I feel.
I'm 4 weeks sober, 28 days yeah yeah! ... I'm clean another day and thankful for that! Hope everyone had a good day, and is staying sober for one more day!
I know I can stay sober one more day, and it's my hope you all will too!
stay clean just for today. Don't give up on yourself, and keep your eye on that prize! We all can, and will, get our lives back in time.
Hang in there guys/gals, it really does get better! Anyone who is struggling, feel free to PM me.

I have decided to go. All my friends know I am in recovery and will not be drinking with them. I have some Antabuse should I need it, but I don't plan on taking it. I feel like this will be a good test. Being so far away, reconnecting with old friends... I'm looking forward to seeing people I haven't seen in two years, I'm looking forward to lying out on the beach and enjoying the sunshine, and I'm looking forward to checking out some NA meetings down there to see how they are.

Stay strong, it really does get better. Especially if you put as much work into recovery as you did active addiction. I've found a new way of life, partially by focusing on my new associations. It's really important to build out a sober network. Doing that makes recovery so much easier. I know the weekend is coming up, so if you're struggling go and check out a meeting, NA AA smart etc. introduce yourself at the beginning and 9/10 someone will come up and introduce themselves after the meeting.
even if you just have the desire to stop using post up and tell us
Anyway, it gets a lot easier. Life's so much fucking better now even on my worst days. Hang in there if you're struggling.

It really does get better, and you really don't have to use opiates anymore. Being sober isn’t a cakewalk, and it’s not all rainbows and unicorns all the time. But it’s a fuck load better than using, for me at least. If you don’t have a place to go, if you’re going thru withdrawal, or you just need someone to talk to; call your local NA hotline.

If your on day 1 or just struggling just know that it gets so much better if you just stick it out and put in some effort. Also, know the only difference between an addict with 10 minutes, 10 days, 10 months, or 10 years of clean time is one bad choice.
Wanted some feedback on the taper schedule
Could I get help with a quick taper schedule

Now after quitting H for almost 2 years it's like I've aged 10 years.  People think I'm in my late 30's to early 40's, and I've gained 25 lbs.  Has anyone else experienced this?  All in all its better now, but damn that sucks haha.
I am starting to feel human again. Praise satan!!!
To everyone: taper and stop fucking using opiates/opioids. It gets better, I promise.
Doing the work. Hating it but doing it and feeling proud of myself at times for doing it.
Do you find that it resets your brain recovery? Sets you up for a fall? Do you find the cravings for DOC worse over the next few days? Or do you find it as an actual quitting aid?
If you can relate, I hope this post helps you not to be like me but better. For yourself.
I just hit 96 hours into my current detox. Feeling a little more human. Rehab is now on the table.
looking forward to the business of getting my shit together and perhaps finally working at some of my root issues
I hope this may be able to give someone hope or encouragement in a dark or hopeless time.
as an addict in early recovery (Feb. 22)
Hi. I'm still clean after 6 months

I promise you that and if you don't,  do your thing I will never judge you...If your in the PNW, and would like some stories or maybe some help you can PM me...I'll listen won't judge, I just want to make a difference! I won't give you money to get dope sorry! You should be good enough at that ...but seriously someone to talk to, Maybe a ride to a job interview?  I'm here I don't attend NA but I still want to help, Whatever I can do let me know, need a meal? Some cigarettes? Naloxone? I'll help all I can
I managed to kick a 8 ball a day habit on 9 suboxin

I've been without heroin for a little bit now, I've had my ups and downs, and it has seemed a lot easier this time around. Sometimes I just think the reality of the situation hasn't hit me yet and I'll be hit in the face with all the problems I've been numbing away all these years. The suboxone helps a lot too, but I'm scared that once it's gone I'll just be running back to heroin.
haven't touch heroin/opiates in a year

So my mom and I looked at our options, got some info, and we decided to try kratom. She drove me straight to the nearest headshop and paid way too much for 75 capsules. I took 2 g initially and another 2 g in the next hour, then got into a boiling hot bath. 2 hours have passed and my hellish withdrawals went from %99 to about %30 now. But God what a huge difference! I'm still very sore and emotional but compared to the brutal blunt misery of acute withdrawal this is RELIEF.

But you CAN do it. You're SO much stronger than you think. The human body is an amazing thing. You can do this. Thousands of people before and after you have and will do this too. But once it's done, you don't ever have to do it again. You're so close to freedom and happiness. It gets better I promise promise promise.
I work steps with a sponsor and attend meetings regularly. Its these things I need to remind myself to be grateful for today, as I'm working through a lot of issues.

So if you're reading this and you're new, give recovery a try. Chances are you didn't stumble into this sub by accident. Something brought you here. I promise you now if you honestly try, your life will get better.
If you're new to recovery, I hope you know that this shit is possible. Rock bottom is only when you decide to stop digging.

The things I've been doing to maintain my sobriety are staying connected to the people I love, especially the few that know about my addiction. On the rare occasions that I get cravings, I talk about it openly to my fiance. We'll usually make some tasteless joke about how much of a junkie I was and that helps to move my thoughts in a different direction. Laughing seems to help me alot. I celebrate small victories, like the first time I went to the movies in 8 years without being high. I work out every day, and I take a walk every day. To everyone in early recovery, the people who tell you that exercise is the best thing you can do for yourself are right. Trust me, I laughed and said fuck all that...until I actually became desperate enough to try it. It works.
I feel so fortunate to be clean
I wish you all the best, at one point in time this was my safe haven, but now I must move on with my life and recovery

Getting sober was the hardest thing I've ever gone through in my life... Just take a moment and make an objective assessment of where you're at today, where you were years past, and where you'd like to be in a few years. If you're not happy with what you find then maybe consider a change.
